Miles Sandlar
November 12th, 2012
Ted Parent
PHIL-3454
The Omnipotent Paradox's Only Solution: Faith

The Problem of Evil arises out of the fact that the existence of evil in the world seem contradictory to co-exist with a 3 Os God in being: omnipotent (all powerful), omnibenevolent (wholy good), and omniesencent (all knowing). The Problem of Evil can be seen as problematic for the theist subscribing to a 3 Os God on several fronts including: Why would an omnibenevolant God continue to allow evil to exist in the world since if God were omnipotent, then God could stop said evil? Why would an omnibenevolant God who is also all knowing create a world or even set into motion a world with evils? The number of apparent contradictions for a 3 Os God arising out of the problem of evil are numerous and seemingly legitamite. A particullarly interesting objection to the Problem of Evil which I would like to focus on is known as the greater good argument (GG). GG attempts to solve the Problem of Evil by showing that: Evil is necessary for greater good. Proceeding, I will how particularly GG can be used to solve the Problem of Evil, how the GG argument fails in its solution in light of the Omnipotent Pardox (OP), and finally offer additionall argumentation in support of OP by refuting potential counterarguments to OP.
Firstly I will provide a reconstruction of the greater good argument which can be found in writings of numerous theist authors. My re-construction will focus primarily on argumentation provided by Gottfried Leibniz in Theodicy: A Defense of Theism. Leibniz presents GG as:
Man was given free will
Out of free will arises evil
Evil enables greater good
Thus: (GG) Evil is a necssary component of greater good
It it necssary at this point that I distinguish what exactly Leibniz means by greater good before I offer counter-argumentation. Greater goods are goods that arise out of virtuous action only enabled by evil. One example of a greater good would be that of the virtuos and wholy good actions seen in response to the tragic event of a hijacked plane crashing into the world trade center on Septermber 11th, 2001. While thousands died on that fateful day, as a result of that tragedy, an even greater good arise. This greater good was that thousands of firefighers and policeman demonstrated the virtes of heroism in saving the lives of innocent civilians trapped in the rubble. Additionally, an entire nation was united for days, weeks, and even years after the attack in mourning. This sense of nationalism and heroism would have never been possible without that initial tragic event. Although Leibniz's GG only implicitly assumes (by name) that greater goods are in fact greater or of more signifigance than normal or first-order goods, it is easy to formulate alternative accounts of GG which explicity state this. Regardless, the matter of wheter greater goods are in fact more valuable than ordinary goods is not essential for GG. As it is such, the value of greater goods are that they outweight the evils in the world needed to produce them.
The main objection I wish to present in the face of GG is that of a nasty side-effect introduced by premise (1), that: Man was given free will. The effect which I speak of is the Omnipotent Paradox (OP) which is best construed by J.L. Mackie in Evil and Omnipotence. Consider the following reconstruction of Mackie's derivation of OP:
God is Omni-Potent, Omni-Benevolant, and Omniescent
If God is Omni-Potent then God can control man's free-will
God can control man's free-will [From 1-2]
Either freedom (free-will) is a virtue God values more than good or God cannot control men's free-will [From 1 & 3]
Freedom is not a virtue God values more than good [From 1]
Thus: God cannot control men's free-will [From 4-5]
Derived from the given assumption of (1) and the harmless additional assumption of (2), resulting: (3) and (6) arise as contradictory -- showing OP. The question the paradox presents us will with is: "can an omni-potent being make things which he cannot subsequently control?". Mackie also adds that OP naturally additionally leads to to the question of: "can an omnipotent being make rule which then bind himself?".
When questioning OP, a first intution for the theist may be to question premise 3. Mainly the theist may ask the question of: is it safe to assume that God values good more than free will? In this vein, the theist may appeal to re-hash the greater good argument in terms of multiple orders of good. If it is such that the theist can re-hash GG such that the sense in which God is omnibenvevolant brings into question the soundness of premise 3, possibly OP could be avoided. To introduce an alternative interpretation of Omnibenevolance, the theist could assert that: while humans understand second order goods, such as herosim (which require evils), there may additionally be third order goods such that only God can understand why they are wholly good. Consequently, the theist could hold that the omnibenevolance that God employs is a third-order good beyond the scope of human understanding. This idea is often re-inforced in common culture with phrases such as "God works in mysterious ways" or "God knows best".
The problem with re-hashing GG in this way to avoid OP is that it is a solution that requires a great deal of of faith. The theist's wants to assert that: God's omnibenevolance is such that we will cannot understand it but somehow regardless of our incoherence of why evils exist, it is for the overarching greater good. I plainly do not see how a completly rational beign could accept this re-hash of GG. This style of reasoning requires siginifigant amounts of faith and is truly best deemed plainly as fideism. To the fideist, I simply do not have the proper deductive argumentation to reply. Irregardless I can show that this re-hash of GG cannot save the theist from the Problem of Evil. As it turns out, OP can be wrought out in presnece of a soley Omnipotent God just as easily as it can be wrought out in presence of a 3 Os God. Consider the following minimal proof which leads to OP assuming only a solely omnipotent God who is not omnibenevolant or omniescencent:
God is Omni-Potent
An Omnipotent God could command that: God himself could no longer control man
Thus: It is possible that god is no longer omnipotent [From 1-2]
This minimal and more generalized derivation of OP shows the unavoidability of the paradox. So then what is it about the setup which leads to the paradox which the theist could possibly bring into question? Well, if theist asserts that at one time God existed and was a 3 Os God however, now God no longer exists... then it looks like you are in the clear of OP. However, a theist arguing for a 3 Os God surely would like to provide a richer notion of God's existence, primarily that the 3 Os God exists now and always will exist. Surely, the thiest would not like to conceed that God is dead. This leads to an alternative counter-argument that the theist could offer playing on the temporal tie of OP, mainly: that God exists outside of the limitaitons temporal order. If the theist insists that God is not constrained by notions of time, that would seem to cripple notion introduction of the OP. As such, God transcends time and thus we cannot understand God's omnipotence from our temporal notions. As such, we simply do not have the proper faculties to say wheter God could or could not perform some action that later impended on his omnipotence. Could God limit his own omnipotence at a later date than he was granted it (if he was so granted)? Well -- that style question the OP brings up cannot even be applied to a God existence indpendent of time.
However, in this light I must emphasize, similariarly as I did with the last objection, that the root of the theist argumentation is that of blind faith. Contorting that God exists independent of time is an assumption that I am not willing to grant for a completly rational agent. Further, from a theologian's perspective this is not the way the 3 Os God is typically portrayed.
Thus, I will grant that if the temporal aspect is elimiated from the the portrayl of a 3 Os God, then OP ceases to be a problem for the theist asserting GG. However, it seems except to avoid the problems introduced by OP, God existing indepdent of temporal order is not in line with the classical theologian's construal of a 3 Os God. So in order to show God's existence to transcend time the theist must either: accept the premise ad-hoc as to avoid OP or simply have faith that this is the case as to avoid OP. Either way seems insufficient but likely to this extent the theist would likely rather accept an argument from faith rather than an ad-hoc argument. Thus, the theist is right back where he started when introduced to OP. As we have seen with each counter-reply to OP, the theist's reasoning must be reducing to a sense of fideism in each instance. I am surely willing to grant that OP is a problem for GG that can be solving numerous ways by requiring faith. I could go on all day listing ways in which the the theist might appeal to faith to dissolve OP, however, we are concerned with logical and deductive discourse. Further, if we are concerned with logical and deductive discourse OP can be seen resulting from GG or simply out of putting forth a soly omnipotent God. Regardless, as seen the only way to solve the OP for the theist is to require faith. However, in the logical discourse we are concerned with... I do not consider requiring faith to show God's existence to be an acceptable solution.
